Problem:
Consider a matrix function \( z(t) \) associated with a complex function \( f(z) = z^2 \), where \( z \) evolves over time according to the differential equation \( \dot{z} = -iz \). We examine how an eigenvalue transformation \( F(z) = e^{\lambda t}z \) affects \( z(t) \), with \( \lambda \) being a complex constant.

If \( F(z) \) is applied to an initial state \( z_0 \) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \( \dot{z} = -iz \) without further intervention, will \( z(t) \) at t = T be the same as if \( z_0 \) was directly evolved under \( \dot{z} = -iz \)?
Explanation: Applying \( F(z) \) changes the initial condition to \( e^{\lambda 0} z_0 = z_0 \), but as time progresses, \( z(t) \) evolves differently due to the exponential term \( e^{\lambda t} \), causing a deviation in trajectory compared to simply evolving \( z_0 \) under \( \dot{z} = -iz \).
